awd_titl_txt: TWC:  Medium:  Secure and Resilient Vehicular Platooning
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of the project is to provide a secure foundation for a transportation system that increasingly relies on the cooperation, connectedness, and automation of vehicles to achieve increases in safety, efficiency, and capacity. The financial losses attributable to congestion in America's transportation infrastructure are more than $1 trillion annually and the parallel loss of life in vehicle collisions is 40,000 deaths per year.  Cooperative, autonomous vehicles are expected to increase the throughput of vehicles; reduce emissions, fuel consumption, and injuries; extend personal transportation to the disabled and elderly; and lessen the number and size of roadways.

This project leverages a multi-disciplinary group, composed of security, transportation, control, and communication researchers to secure an automated transportation system that is available to all vehicles, trusted or not, that may experience impaired connectivity.  The team is (1) developing a secure and resilient control regime for automated vehicles, (2) building a framework based on the physical layer to enable vehicles to establish peer trust, and (3) providing a trusted infrastructure the ability to securely gather and disseminate traffic and environmental data to vehicles for optimal route planning and accident avoidance using Bayesian inference on Markov models.

The proposed research will advance the knowledge in many fields: secure and resilient control, VANET security, trust establishment and management, physical-layer security, decision theory, and secure protocol design. Results from this research will be disseminated in peer-reviewed journals and conferences. The research will provide opportunities for research training for underrepresented students at undergraduate and graduate levels.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of the project was to provide a secure foundation for a transportation system that increasingly relies on cooperative automation strategies and vehicle connectedness to achieve increases in safety, efficiency, and capacity. This project contributed to the research and development of secure connected and automated vehicles (CAV) and a smart transportation infrastructure by: 1) showing how vehicles may securely communicate with each other without the need for a central authority, thus enhancing user privacy and minimizing the need for infrastructure modifications; 2) demonstrating that while attacks against CAV are possible they may be identified and mitigated by trading efficiency for safety; 3) validating several approaches to prevent maliciously-controlled vehicles from causing accidents or altering traffic flow by verifying the movements of vehicles; 4) providing algorithms that would allow a CAV to navigate uncertain environments, according to user-defined safety requirements and preferences, even if the information it is receiving from other CAV is untrustworthy; and 5) exposing, and suggesting countermeasures for, how human oversight of CAV functionality can be manipulated to induce traffic congestion and accidents and how machine learning systems in CAV may be manipulated from a distance to, for example, fail to notice a stop sign at a busy intersection.


The project showed that while both semi-automated  (e.g., adaptive cruise control) and fully-automated vehicle functionality can be exploited by an attacker to jeopardize the safety of persons within vehicles or make travel untenable (by, e.g., inducing stop-and-go traffic), such malicious actions can be detected, identified, and mitigated.  In leveraging an adversarial approach to the examination of CAV operations the project made these systems more resilient to non-malicious faults and errors.


Project efforts and funds contributed, in whole or part, to eleven M.S. theses and eight Ph.D. dissertations in STEM areas, in addition to providing research experiences for over ten undergraduates across four institutions.  Over 30 publications were produced.
